comments.author: Wilbur Jenkins

comments.text:
+Anona Moose
Actually, there is a lot said about selling drugs on social media. I don't 
know about the military producing heroin from Afghanistan, but opium is one 
of Afghanistan's biggest exports, the poppy flower grows there like grass, 
and there a lot of people in the business of producing it. Is your next 
argument going to be that handguns are so serious that Colt is in the 
business of making the 1911. They cannot charge him with it because of time 
limit laws dictating that basically say that after a certain period of 
time, you cannot be charged with crimes unless it's rape, murder, or 
something else extreme or violent (it doesn't say extreme, it actually is a 
very detailed list). They do keep records of horses in there. It might be 
the world's biggest data center, but while they were spying on everyone and 
their dog, these are the same people who couldn't stop the Boston bombings, 
and had no clue where to start right after it happened. Should there be a 
day when the government wants to get that strict, dig up people's past, and 
violate constitutional rights, there are going to be a lot of things that 
are better to worry about. Your argument might be technically correct in 
some ways, but you also have to look at the reality of the situation.
comments.author: Garrett Baschenvloir

comments.text: Couldn't agree more, so damn sad.
comments.author: TheInfamousWolf

comments.text:
+Garrett Baschenvloir Yes, on social media there is a lot of talk about 
marijuana but its mostly about smoking it, not selling it. Heroin is a far 
more serious drug than marijuana, its so serious the US military is in the 
business of producing it straight from Afghanistan. 

If the NSA has records of him self snitching, you think later on if the 
government believes he got out of hand by maybe lets say participating in a 
protest, wouldn't they just arrest him and bring up his records of him 
being a drug dealer and heroin addict, etc etc.? NSA built the worlds 
largest data center, they don't keep records of horses in there bro.
comments.author: Anona Moose

comments.text:
+Anona Moose
First of all, he said he WAS a heroin addict, secondly, you need to wake 
up. The NSA probably does have an algorithm for that, but if you ever get 
on any social media, you will find people talking about it, and they never 
go away. Technically, it does warrant a search, but there are better things 
to worry about.
comments.author: Garrett Baschenvloir

comments.text:
+Garrett Baschenvloir He also said that he is a heroin addict. Is that 
legal too? Bad behavior and admittance warrants a search, you think the NSA 
doesn't have some special algorithm to check for people who comment about

comments.author: Anona Moose

comments.author: Anona Moose

comments.text:

I can go down the street into a weed shop, just like a liquor store
comments.author: Logan Silver

comments.text:
Thank you. I have a friend who was caught selling pills, I knew he did and 
sold a little bit of weed here and there (between friends and stuff), and 
that he had access to a few pills, but when I was told what he went down 
for, I was shocked. He was making $1,000 to $2,000 a week selling 
controlled medication, occasionally a little bit of meth, and little bit of 
weed (between some friends). He was charged with felony distribution, and 
what got him off the hook, was that he was a sophomore in high school, as 
was I. You couldn't pick him out of a crowd, he was just your typical 
funny, fluffy, high school student who drove a little old beat up Buick, 
and lived in a slightly older middle class neighborhood. He was able to 
maintain his operation for about a year because he blended in, like the kid 
in the video. People need to realize that it isn't some "racist system", 
and that the way you act, is a big part in the way you are perceived. If 
you're lower class, and have a new Cadillac with chrome rims and roll up 
into your drive way in the projects, and get out with shoe game, and you're 
not even "fresh", and just have that ghetto thug mentality and behavior, 
you're going to get caught. My friend and the kid in the video are savvy 
because they looked like everyone else while rolling in an exceptional 
amount of cash, and they both had a fairly long term operation. My friend's 
operation was constantly evolving to avoid getting caught, and when he did 
get caught, there wasn't much on him, because entire operation was dim, and 
he was constantly cleaning up after himself, not leaving a trail or any 
direct evidence. Due to this, he got a light sentence, even in terms of the 
juvenile system. Maximum gain, minimum loss, and it's all due to behavior, 
which is what idiots need to understand, but yet then again, why have 
intelligence when you have the race card.

I know someone who was a substitute teacher in the juvenile justice system, 
and she is a sociology major. She and a few other sociologists were 
assigned to do demographics work on the juvenile system, and in their 
findings, when they asked inmates "why are you in here", or "what have you 
been charged with" (no statements that assume guilt though, to be fair to 
the individual), they found that lower class inmates, along with minorities 
(specifically African Americans) would typically have a response that 
admitted to breaking the law, but not doing anything wrong, and they would 
blame being in there on someone else, not their own actions. One example 
was when she asked one inmate "why are you in here", and his response was 
"someone told on me". Now, if you analyze that statement, there is no "I 
was caught" or "I did this and someone turned me in", instead they are 
placing the blame on someone else, and taking no responsibility for their 
own actions. They also found that African American adolescents in a house 
receiving a lot of government aid, specifically government funded housing, 
had the most self-centered and narcissistic mentality of any other inmates 
in that facility. One 16 year old in there had shot 6 people total, 5 of 
which died as a direct result of their injuries, in gang related hits over 
the past 4 years. When she talked to him, his response was, and I quote "I 
was keepin' it real in da hood you know", his head was up, he had a lot of 
pride, and just that thug/thug wannabe behavior. He later on went to say 
that the officer didn't have to shoot him (he was shot twice while being 
arrested in a crack house raid, I've seen the helmet cam, he fired at the 
officers and took two shots to the chest right after that, a third round 
skimmed his shoulder), and that the officers were "racist" (despite the 
fact more than 2/3s of the officers performing the raid were black, and the 
operation organizer was black, and the head detective, and the head of the 
sting operation), and as you know, he said all of this in a stupid ghetto 
language that I'm ashamed to be able to depict (I don't know why though, 
because I've rarely ever been exposed to it), that makes anyone who speaks 
it fluently sound like a complete moron who needs to get their head checked 
and go back to kindergarten. This is all an example of people not taking 
responsibility for their own actions, and they have been raised to believe 
that they can do no wrong.
comments.author: Garrett Baschenvloir

comments.author: MichiganFann

comments.author: Joshua Colicchia

comments.text:
In reality the size of that grow operation (at least the photo shown in 
this video) and the fact they only found 9k in the kids house... it sounds 
like the police made a controlled buy and more than likely got ripped 
off... 20 bucks a gram or more.  So they extrapolated that the amount being 
grown would produce enough to make 20k a month if sold at extremely high 
prices in small quantities.

Overall it doesn't take brain surgery to profit from someone you know that 
is growing pot.  Everyone knows at least one person that smokes it... then 
that person knows at least one person and so on.  It's how the black market 
continues to roll on.

Now if we heard about this kid pulling it off and writing a book 20 years 
later and not got busted in that time frame... sure.  Heck if he was the 
one actually growing the pot for two years this story would be notable as 
the kid was smart or business savvy.  Since he'd have to grow it and keep 
it under wraps.  To handle transactions... any moron w/ friends can do that.

I'm with Ana on this... how in the hell did the parents not realize?  It 
smells like they were involved in some way or this kid hasn't profited near 
as much as the police want to tout.  I know when I got busted right after 
honorably exiting the army (while collecting unemployment from 
discharge)... the local police made me out to be a drug dealing king pin.  

I was allegedly the biggest drug dealer and the dominican connection for 
the past two years in my area.  I was stationed overseas in Korea for 
several months they alleged I was dealing.  Then was at Ft. Hood with the 
1st Air Cav for a year of the allegations.  Easily refuted unless as a 
scout I was out practicing or making war plus in my "spare time" (LoL) I 
was flying back to johnstown to sell pot.  It is true I made friends who 
were Dominican while in the Army but I never sold drugs while enlisted nor 
was ever busted making a sale to this date.  My overall point is I'm sure 
this is just another sensationalized "news" report about this kid.﻿
comments.author: Lee DeCoske
